title: Where Is Crown Prince Mohammed?

title: For the ACLU, Antipathy to Israel Trumps Antidiscrimination
summary: Laws against boycotting the Jewish state are patterned after those that protect gays and lesbians.. Identity politics guides its adherents in strange directions. The American Civil Liberties Union, which for decades defended the vulnerable against public discrimination, has begun an assault on several antidiscrimination laws. Its goal is to bring boycotts of Israel into the political mainstream.

title: Emancipation Deniers Target Lincoln's Reputation
summary: He offered 'verbal cake and ice cream to slaveowners,' claimed popular leftist historian Howard Zinn.. In an age when rocking century-old statues off their pedestals has become a public sport, no historical reputation is safe. That includes Abraham Lincoln, the Great Emancipator.

title: 'The Future Is Asian' Review: Global Power Shifting East
summary: Is the decline of the West, so long predicted, now within sight? A loosely uniﬁed Asian "megaregion" may be its replacement.. Assessing the state of the West today-from the nationalism roiling Europe to America's fresh skepticism of long-held alliances and global commitments-some might wonder whether the Western world order is on the brink of a breakdown. If it is, what will replace it? Parag Khanna, a Singapore-based global-strategy adviser, has one answer. In "The Future Is Asian," he argues that the world's largest continent-Mr. Khanna would say "megaregion"-is becoming increasingly blended into one political, cultural and economic unit poised to overtake a waning West.

title: Trucker New England Motor Freight Files for Bankruptcy, Plans Shutdown
summary: The filing comes after a strong year for trucking companies. New England Motor Freight Inc., a major player in the competitive New York regional trucking market, sought bankruptcy protection Monday and intends to wind down operations.

title: Green New Deal: A Cautionary Tale
summary: Australia's costly and fatal 2009 effort to upgrade houses for energy efficiency.. Sydney

title: Incredible Shrinking Europe
summary: The Continent's grand unity project is failing, and its global influence is fading.. Last week offered fresh evidence that the most consequential historical shift of the last 100 years continues: the decline of Europe as a force in world affairs. As Deutsche Bank warned of a German recession, the European Commission cut the 2019 eurozone growth forecast from an already anemic 1.9% to 1.3%. Economic output in the eurozone was lower in 2017 than it was in 2009; over that same period, gross domestic product grew 139% in China, 96% in India, and 34% in the U.S., according to the World Bank.

title: Ralph Northam 'Apologizes'
summary: Virginia's governor seeks to buy political redemption by becoming more woke.. For all those who thought the Ralph Northam story couldn't possibly get worse, the Virginia governor's "apology" may turn out to be more toxic than the original offense.

summary: Allegations under investigation that officials urged that criminal prosecution of Montreal firm be dropped. summary: The U.K.'s economy notched its slowest annual growth in six years in 2018, data show. The dollar notched its seventh consecutive day of gains Monday, as economic concerns weighed on the euro and British pound, while the Swiss franc recovered from a sharp early-session decline.

summary: Meeting officials frustrated by exclusion from Taliban talks, acting secretary affirms security commitment. The Pentagon's top official assured Afghanistan's government on Monday that the U.S. wouldn't desert the country's security forces, the Afghan Defense Ministry said, signaling American support for the jittery government while the U.S. holds talks with the Taliban to end the country's 17-year war.

title: This Decorating Puzzle Almost Stumped the Pros
summary: A quiet cane bed must share a bedroom with a clamorous red-lacquered bureau. Design experts suggest pieces to bridge the aesthetic gap. Which solution do you think works best?. Bring in a lamp that is itself both restrained and wild. New York designer Lindsey Coral Harper recommends this Bunny Williams Home light. Energetic brush strokes a la abstract expressionist Franz Kline modernize the familiar double-gourd form and plain shade. "Like the bed's caning, parts of the lamp are traditional, but its unconventional twist speaks to the bureau," said Ms. Harper. Brush Stroke Lamp, $950, bunnywilliamshome.com

title: Latest Funding Values Reddit at $3 Billion
summary: China's Tencent provides more than half of $300 million in new financing. title: Is Adam Schiff Satisfied with NBC News?
summary: Two years after telling the network he had 'more than circumstantial evidence' he still hasn't produced it.. NBC News proudly notes that "Meet the Press" is the longest-running program on network television. But it's unlikely anyone at the network will be looking back with pride on this week's show. Almost two full years after Rep. Adam Schiff (D., Calif.) told NBC he had seen "more than circumstantial evidence" that associates of Donald Trump had colluded with Russia to rig the 2016 election, the network not only welcomed him back without demanding that he finally produce the evidence to support his claim. NBC gave him a platform to make new allegations.

title: The Rolls-Royce Cullinan SUV Is Massive-and Will Not Be Ignored
summary: Reminiscent of Rolls-Royce hunting cars from the 1920s, the new Cullinan SUV is a return to form for the brand, says Dan Neil, with titanic dimensions, off-road capabilities and, wait, a tea set?. BACK WHEN TIGERS were plentiful and Rolls-Royces were rare, the rajahs of India would commission special hunting cars, from which their owners could comfortably blast away at charismatic megafauna. The most famous such car is a 1925 Barker-bodied Phantom I, owned by Maharajah of Kotah, Umed Singh II. His Highness's Roller was built on a raised chassis and was powered by an 8-liter inline-six and four-speed gearbox, with a low-speed ratio for off-roading. It towed an antiaircraft machine gun for extra big game. Nice.

summary: Investors weigh supply worries against broader macroeconomic concerns. • Oil prices fell to a two-week low Monday due to a stronger dollar and simmering concerns that unresolved U.S.-China trade negotiations could hurt the global economy and reduce oil demand.

summary: Metal maker to restart construction at Alabama plant as higher steel prices bolster domestic mills' profit. title: The Hottest New Fashion Trend for Men Is...Harnesses?
summary: Actors like Timothée Chalamet, Michael B. Jordan and Chadwick Boseman have been wearing an unexpected accessory this awards season. Here's the story behind the male harness. ON JULY 18, 2018, Chadwick Boseman wore a white, chest-spanning leather harness over his cream-colored tuxedo to the ESPY Awards. Months later, Timothée Chalamet showed up at the Golden Globes in a glittery gothic version of the harness and Michael B. Jordan, not to be outdone, strapped on a floral embroidered one for the Screen Actors Guild Awards. This trio of body-crossing contraptions, all from Virgil Abloh's first collection as Louis Vuitton's menswear designer, have confounded awards-show followers. Are the harnesses bedazzled gun holsters? Sparkly black lederhosen? Toddler reins for adults? For my money, they most resemble lopsided seatbelts.

title: In Franca Sozzani's Letters, A Son Sees His Mother's Creative Spirit
summary: The late Vogue Italia editor left boxes of correspondence with famous artists. Her son, documentarian Francesco Carrozzini, talks about going through them for the first time. Sifting through piles of paper in his late mother's Milanese apartment, Francesco Carrozzini, son of the legendary editor Franca Sozzani, was not surprised she had famous pen pals. He was surprised, however, by her tone: "There is a lot of humor in what she wrote-and in what she did," the Emmy-nominated documentarian, 36, says. "And all in a business that takes itself very, very seriously." Those lively letters go public for the first time in Franca: Chaos & Creation (Assouline), a 408-page book out this month and a companion to Carrozzini's 2016 film of the same name. The anthologizing, which combined those notes with reprints of Franca's most famous Vogue shoots-along with fond recollections from the likes of Carla Bruni Sarkozy and Anna Wintour, now Carrozzini's mother-in-law-was a grueling, multiyear research project, he says. The release now coincides with both a Yoox sale of his mother's personal wardrobe and the establishment of a Harvard Medical School-affiliated fund for genomics research in her name. Ahead of publication, Carrozzini reflects on his mother's legacy.

title: A Look Inside Franca: Chaos and Creation

Across the U.S., more employers are handing out activity trackers and rolling out high-tech wellness programs that aim to keep closer tabs on workers' exercise, sleep and nutrition, and ultimately cut ballooning health-care costs.

title: Well-Sited Wind Towers Make Good Sense
summary: The mischaracterization that two shuttered wind turbines in Falmouth, Mass., represent the 56,000 operating U.S. wind turbines misleads readers.. Regarding your editorial "A Green New Deal in Profile" (Feb. 5): The two shuttered wind turbines in Falmouth, Mass., do not represent the 56,000 operating U.S. wind turbines. Falmouth's project was exceptionally unusual.

title: Soaking the Rich, Sinking the Yacht Builders
summary: Progressives don't understand that part of the genius of markets is that they inherently soak the rich.. Regarding Jason L. Riley's "How a Billionaire Spends His Money Is His Own Business" (Upward Mobility, Jan. 30): The assumption behind the "soak the rich" tactics of the left is that only money coerced from the wealthy through taxation provides social benefit. This is profoundly untrue. Of the five things one can do with money-spend, invest, donate to charity, pay taxes and hoard-all but the last provide economic benefit to the rest of us, and in roughly the order listed, from most to least.

title: More Choices for Veterans Limited by Slow Payments
summary: Relaxing the rules won't help veterans if the slow payment problem isn't corrected.. Regarding your editorial "Veterans Are Freer to Choose" (Feb. 6): I guess it could be a good thing for the Department of Veterans Affairs to relax its rules allowing veterans to go to doctors of their choosing. A doctor within 30 miles versus 40 miles or a 28-day waiting period for appointments would certainly benefit many vets, including my husband. However, it has been our firsthand experience that few private doctors, clinics or facilities are willing to accept VA assignments because of the amount of time it takes for them to receive payment for their services. This issue isn't addressed in the editorial. Relaxing the rules won't help veterans if the slow payment problem isn't corrected. Recently my husband was being treated by a private physical therapist. The therapist had to drop him because he had not received payment in more than six months from the date of service.

title: The California Cup Fee May Have a Benefit, After All
summary: California's "cup fee" may or may not turn out to be effective, but Christian Britschgi's argument that it will not be is unconvincing.. Regarding the Notable & Quotable of Jan. 29: California's "cup fee" may or may not turn out to be effective, but Christian Britschgi's argument that it will not be is unconvincing. He rightly suggests that merchants may simply lower the retail price of a cup by $0.25, canceling out any additional cost to consumers and leaving merchant costs unchanged. However, there would remain an incentive for consumers to bring their own cup and save the quarter. If, say, half the consumers in Berkeley did so, that would be quite effective.

title: Who in Government Really Is Helping the Russians?
summary: Had President Trump been the one soft-pedaling Russia's treaty violations and proposing more talks, wouldn't Democrats have howled that he was in league with Vladimir Putin?. Regarding your editorial "When Arms Control Fails" (Feb. 2): Although there is no doubt that Russia's deployment of medium-range cruise missiles in Europe violates the 1987 Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces Treaty, the Trump administration's decision to start withdrawing from the INF has upset Democrats and unsettled European allies. Ten Senate Democrats, including three 2020 presidential candidates, introduced a bill to force the U.S. to follow the INF Treaty unilaterally, while discussions take place to work Russia back into compliance.

title: Iran Vows to Continue Military Expansion Despite U.S. Threats
summary: President Rouhani said Tehran doesn't need permission to develop ballistic missiles. President Hassan Rouhani and other Iranian leaders Monday used mass celebrations of the 1979 revolution to lash out against the U.S. and reaffirm Tehran's pledge to continue developing ballistic-missile systems that Washington says threatens the region's security.

summary: Oxiris Barbot is reorganizing New York City's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, aiming for 'a different way of doing business'. Oxiris Barbot is waiting patiently to hold the baby.

title: The Grande Dame of Garden Design Shares Her Favorite Things
summary: Arabella Lennox-Boyd on the art, drawing board, gloves and more she loves. "My passion for collecting trees started in 1990. By now I've planted more than 7,000 at Gresgarth Hall [in Lancashire, England]. The Pinus lambertiana pine cone in the middle of the table is native to Oregon and California; it's indicative of my passion for growing trees from seed. The painting of an enlarged nigella seed above was done by Brigid Edwards, who I think, along with Rory McEwen, is one of the greatest botanical painters ever. The Piranesi print of the Teatro di Marcello [in Rome], which is an original from the 1700s, shows where I was brought up. I lived right up at the top with a view of the Temple of Vesta. When you go to Rome in April, there are these lovely azaleas indica, which you can see here in the pot on the floor. On the left side of the table is a collection of books by Vita Sackville-West. When I originally came over to England around 1967, the first garden I saw was hers. I always liked the way she wrote about plants, as if they were friends. Below is a Rotring A3 drawing board, which has a master plan of a garden I did for Trudie [Styler] and Sting. It's my favorite because it's light and I can carry it with me. My husband, Mark, designed the grabber in front. He copied it from one owned by the great gardener Princess Greta Sturdza. She had this amazing garden in Normandy. Both my daughters are artists. One of them, Dominique Lacloche, made the bronze sculpture of a gunnera leaf, in the center of the table, as a Christmas present for me. My other daughter, Patricia L. Boyd, works with sculpture and video. The Showa gloves to the right are the only ones I can garden in. They're very light and easy to wear. On top are Felco secateurs. The wonderful thing is if your blade goes blunt you can send them back and they put a new one in for you. The Uzbek cushion on the lower right is one of my favorites. I like the landscapes of these very wild countries that also have these wonderful materials, patterns and artifacts. I bought the Chinese lantern either in Kunming or Beijing 16 years ago. It's made of very fine metal with this lovely pattern, and inside there's a type of gauze, so the light of a candle is gentle. I fell in love with the beauty of the country and the energy of the people in it. I traveled to China four times after that. I often go walking in the mountains to look at trees." -As told to Tobias Grey

title: China Pushes Back Against Turkey's Criticism of Its Uighur Detentions

House Democrats are planning to unveil Medicare for All legislation soon, turning up the heat on Democratic presidential candidates facing questions over how far they want to go in embracing a national government health system.

title: Trump to Hold Rally at the Border as Funding Talks Stall
summary: President to rally for border wall funding as another potential government shutdown looms. President Trump will return in earnest to campaign mode on Monday, holding his first rally of the year in the shadow of the Mexican border and in the hometown of a potential rival, former Democratic Rep. Beto O'Rourke.

title: Hey, Big Spender: Tech Cash Will Keep Flowing
summary: Investments in cloud networks still likely to expand in the coming year, despite cautious tone. The demise of big tech spending has been greatly exaggerated.

title: The Dreaded Earnings Slowdown Is Here
summary: Fears about fourth-quarter earnings for U.S. companies were overblown; but the first quarter is looking shaky, and it may start weighing on stocks. Companies' fourth-quarter earnings weren't nearly as bad as investors feared. The first quarter isn't looking bright, though, and that could create a big divide between the market's haves and have-nots.

title: PG&E Board: No More Than Five Directors Will Run for Re-Election
summary: California utility-hurt by more $30 billion in wildfire liabilities-filed for bankruptcy in January. Five of PG&E Corp.'s current board directors at the maximum will be up for re-election at the company's annual shareholder meeting, the company's board said Monday.

title: EQT Buys Gas-Compression Company From Stephens Group
summary: Firm is banking on increasing oil-and-gas production in the U.S. with this deal. The infrastructure team of European private-equity firm EQT is banking on growing U.S. oil-and-gas production with its acquisition of Kodiak Gas Services LLC, a provider of compression equipment and services to the energy industry.

title: Prices of Pickup Trucks Charge Into Luxury-Car Territory
summary: Auto makers add plusher interiors, more powerful engines and premium options like massage seats and touch screens. Pickup trucks that cost $50,000 or more were a rarity on dealer lots a decade ago. But Detroit's auto makers, eager for new sources of income, have been steadily yanking up truck prices-and finding that buyers will pay up for better engines and more frills.

title: KPMG Ex-Partner Goes on Trial in 'Steal the Exam' Scandal
summary: Prosecutors say an effort to help the Big Four accounting firm look better to its regulator broke the law. A criminal trial that starts Monday may shed more light on a high-profile scandal at KPMG LLP: an effort to help the Big Four accounting firm look better to its regulator that prosecutors say broke the law.

title: Rural U.S. Carriers Resist Proposed Telecom Ban Aimed at Huawei
summary: Plan faces resistance from companies whose networks run on Huawei equipment. WASHINGTON-President Trump is weighing an executive order that could ban Chinese telecommunications gear from U.S. networks, but the plan is facing resistance from U.S. carriers in rural areas whose networks run on Huawei Technologies Co. equipment.

title: At the Water's Edge, Seaports Are Slowly Bracing for Rising Ocean Levels
summary: While some ports are raising critical infrastructure higher off the ground, preparations at many trade gateways will fit into longer-term construction plans. When the Port of Virginia began a sweeping renovation of its major Norfolk International Terminals, some easy-to-miss line items on the $375 million agenda included boosting the site's electric power stations several feet off the ground and adding data servers as far back from the water as possible.

title: Storms Trigger a Surge in Boston Infrastructure Plans
summary: Massport is bracing for the sea level to rise by up to 40 inches by 2070. Boston's role on global ocean-trade maps isn't very big, but the port city could provide a big example of how to brace coastal facilities against rising sea waters.

title: New York Gov. Cuomo's Ratings Sink in New Poll
summary: The survey found U.S. Sens. Chuck Schumer and Kirsten Gillibrand also lost standing, as did the New York state Senate and Assembly. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo's favorability rating plummeted in the past month, a poll released Monday shows, part of an overall slide in standing for New York's Democratic politicians.

title: Flu Drug Was Called 'Silver Bullet,' but Some Doctors Prescribe Caution
summary: Researchers in Japan find evidence that some strains of the virus are resistant to the new Xofluza pill. TOKYO-A new pill that can kill the flu virus in 24 hours with a single dose has become the most-prescribed influenza treatment in Japan, which is suffering through its worst flu season in two decades.

title: Chinese Investment in Israel Raises Security Fears
summary: U.S., Israeli security officials are concerned about Beijing's tech investments. TEL AVIV-Security officials are raising alarms over Chinese investment in Israeli technology companies, prompting the Israeli government to scrutinize the money flows and businesses to reconsider accepting Chinese funds.

title: Parsing of Audit Work Creates Opening for Technology Firms
summary: Digitized record-keeping is enabling technology companies to play a role in the annual audit. More companies are splitting the annual financial audit into two segments-data gathering and analysis-a move that could enable them to more easily outsource portions of the audit process to technology companies.

title: This Options Bet Helps Tame Markets, but There Are Risks
summary: 'Reach for yield' behavior underscores concerns about the nearly decade-old bull market in U.S. stocks, some analysts say. More investors are selling options in a bid to boost returns, a shift that traders say is helping to tamp down market volatility now-but potentially at the expense of greater turbulence later.

title: U.K. Posts Slowest Growth in Six Years Amid Brexit Worries
summary: Falling investment was largely responsible for the slowdown. The U.K. economy experienced its weakest growth in six years during 2018 as businesses slashed investment in the face of growing uncertainty about the way in which the country will leave the European Union.

title: Amid Gloomy Data, a Hopeful Sign for Chinese Stocks
summary: Resume Subscription. Chinese stocks are off to a solid start this year after being among the world's worst-performing markets in 2018. As hopes grow for a forceful official response to a slowdown, one gauge suggests more money is coursing through the financial system, a development that could also boost shares.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Trump Seeks to Boost AI as Chinese Competition Grows
summary: President to sign order directing federal agencies to prioritize artificial intelligence in their R&D. WASHINGTON-President Trump is expected to sign an executive order Monday aimed at boosting U.S. development of artificial intelligence-and at blunting China's momentum in the field.

title: Giving to Colleges Jumps 7.2% to Record $46.7 Billion
summary: Seven schools received gifts of at least $100 million in fiscal 2018.

title: Kacey Musgraves Wins Album of the Year at the Grammys
summary: Alicia Keys hosts the music industry's awards ceremony, with an expanded field of nominees competing for the top prizes. Kacey Musgraves won album of the year at the Grammy Awards, the music industry's most prestigious prize, for her critically acclaimed "Golden Hour."

title: U.S. Mideast Commander Sees Syria Withdrawal 'Right on Track'
summary: Equipment being moved, troops on pace to start leaving in weeks amid victories over Islamic State, general says. ABOARD A U.S. MILITARY AIRCRAFT-The top U.S. commander in the Middle East said the military is pulling equipment out of Syria in preparation for a troop withdrawal that comes as the U.S.-led coalition has entered what it says is the last stages of its fight against Islamic State in Syria.

title: One Man's Quest for Financial Security and Flexibility at Work
summary: A music-industry professional in his 40s is debt-free and focused on saving in order to have work flexibility later in his career. After getting divorced and paying off a sizable amount of credit-card debt, Matthew Barnhart has spent years focusing on his finances. His goal: To be able to turn down work that doesn't appeal to him.

title: Impeachment Plan for Fairfax Drafted in Virginia
summary: Justin Fairfax defies widespread calls to resign after second woman accuses Democrat of sexual assault. Democratic legislators in Virginia circulated Sunday afternoon a draft resolution to start impeachment proceedings against Lt. Gov. Justin Fairfax over two allegations of sexual assault.

title: Forget the 401(k). Let's Invent a New Retirement Plan.
summary: Ideas include allowing your savings to follow you wherever you go or however you work. If we could reinvent retirement-saving plans from scratch, how would they differ from the rigid and often paltry 401(k)s that workers have today?

title: Why Retirees Are Wary of Annuities
summary: Understanding the reason for their reluctance may help people make better investment choices. One of the biggest challenges to a successful retirement is making sure you don't run out of money once you begin tapping your nest egg.

title: A Millennial's Take on Venmo Etiquette
summary: When it comes to repaying friends, mobile apps have multiplied the opportunities for missteps. A millennial offers his take. Where to begin?

title: How Big Must Your Nest Egg Be?
summary: Also: We answer a reader's question about what Medicare does and doesn't cover. How can I figure out how much money I need to save for retirement? How big does my nest egg need to be?

title: Smart Ways to Be a Tax-Savvy Investor
summary: Don't make investment decisions solely for tax purposes. But don't ignore taxes either.. Investment pros often remind clients: It's not how much you make that counts. It's how much you take home after tax collectors grab their share.

title: The Surprising Problem of Having Too Many College Scholarships
summary: Outside awards can lead to scholarship displacement, which reduces the amount of a school's aid package. When it comes to college scholarships, more could mean less.

title: The Benefits of Starting College Early-in High School
summary: Dual-enrollment programs are expanding to a younger and more diverse group of students. Here's one way to help students complete college on time, and with less debt: start earlier. As a result, some educators and policy makers are making college-level courses available to more high-school students.

title: What's Behind the Surge in Giving Circles
summary: This collaborative approach to philanthropy is being driven by millennials and women. Adriana Loson-Ceballos wanted to help support nonprofits serving the Latino community in San Diego. But as a doctoral student, she didn't have much money to donate and worried that her gift wouldn't be large enough to make a real impact.

title: Art Donors Increasingly Look to University Museums
summary: College art museums are more likely to display donated works, keep collections together and incorporate them into the academic curriculum. Owners of large art collections often envision themselves eventually donating their works to a major museum, where the pieces can be viewed by the masses. But once such works become part of a museum's massive permanent collection, they often end up in storage and rarely if ever displayed.

title: What to Ask Before Investing in a Hedge Fund
summary: Understanding a fund's strategy should be straightforward. If it isn't, don't invest.. Hedge-fund returns have lagged behind stocks for almost a decade. But as market volatility and uncertainty increases, sophisticated investors may start considering certain hedge-fund strategies that can do well in all kinds of markets, especially when prices are bouncing all over the place.

title: The Democrats' Identity Meltdown
summary: The furies they unleashed are consuming their own. Where's Barack?. Democrats need an identity-politics intervention. Having unleashed race, gender, sexual orientation and class as the defining issues of American politics, these furies are now consuming their authors. Where's Barack Obama when Democrats need him?

title: Honeymoon Ends for Albany's Democratic Leaders
summary: Gov. Cuomo is pushing back on opposition within his party to the Amazon deal and calls to increase taxes.. After 39 days, the Pax Democratica at the Capitol is over.

title: GOP Congressman Who Opposed Iraq War Dies at 76
summary: Walter Jones of North Carolina was booster of 'Freedom Fries' in 2003, a Trump critic in recent years. WASHINGTON-Rep. Walter Jones, a 12-term Republican congressman from North Carolina known for his opposition to the Iraq war and, more recently, his criticism of President Trump, died on Sunday. He was 76.

title: Turkey Calls on China to End Mass Incarceration of Muslim Uighurs
summary: Concern over fate of Uighur musician prompts Turkey to call Beijing's internment camps for minority Muslims 'a great shame for humanity'. BEIJING-Turkey demanded that China end its mass incarceration of Turkic Muslims, as concern over the fate of a well-regarded Uighur musician in China prompted a rare public rebuke of the forced assimilation campaign from a government in the Muslim world.

title: As Democratic Field Grows, the 2020 Race Sharpens in Tone
summary: As Klobuchar, Warren jump into the race, Trump tries to define his potential opponents early. WASHINGTON-President Trump and a growing field of Democratic presidential contenders are entering a more confrontational phase at the start of the 2020 campaign, with the incumbent seeking to define his opponents long before the general election.

title: Bryce Harper Is Playing Hardball. He Should Play Softball.
summary: Manny Machado remains unsigned too! Here's an open invitation from The Wall Street Journal to a pair of major leaguers looking for a home team.. Bryce Harper is one of the best players in baseball. He is a six-time All-Star and former MVP who has consistently been one of the top offensive performers in the league. He is just 26 years old, with plenty of career ahead of him. He also has fantastic hair. I mean, it's truly fantastic-as if a unicorn's mane was sculpted by a Beverly Hills salon.

title: Prepare to Pay More for Diapers, Clorox and Cat Litter
summary: Big brands plan further price increases for household staples after finding some success doing so last year. Makers of household staples from diapers to toilet paper are set to raise prices again this year after already hiking prices in 2018, hoping to offset higher commodity costs and boost profits.
